SONNET TO THE MEMORY OF THOMAS GRAY AUTHOR OF THE ODES ENTITLED, THE PROGRESS OF POETRY AND THE BARD, AND OF THE ELEGY IN A COUNTRY CHURCH-YARD, etc. Lord of the various lyre! devout we turn Our pilgrim steps to thy supreme abode, And tread with awe the solitary road To grace with votive wreaths thy hallow'd urn. Yet, as we wander through this dark sojourn, No more the strains we hear, that all abroad Thy fancy wafted as the inspiring God Prompted the thoughts that breathe, the words that burn. But hark: a voice in solemn accents clear Bursts from heav'n's vault that glows with temperate fire; Cease, mortal, cease to drop the fruitless tear, Mute though the raptures of his full-strung lyre; E'en his own warblings, lessen'd on his ear, Lost in seraphick harmony expire. STANZAS FOR MUSICK. As now the shades of eve imbrown The scenes where pensive poets rove, From care remote, from envy's frown The joys of inward calm I prove. What holy strains around me swell! No wildly rude tumultuous sound: They fix the soul by magick spell: Soft let me tread this favour'd ground. Sweet is the gale that breathes the spring, Sweet through the vale yon winding stream, Sweet is the note those warblers sing, But sweeter Friendship's soothing theme. A MARINE DIRGE. Written during the French Revolution. 1 Heard you the strain from yonder sky On Albion burst in choral majesty? See his throne great Ocean leave; The deities, who round him wait, Attend upon his state: The firm earth shakes; the billows heave; And from the deep Tritonian shell Slow solemn-breathing notes o'er Belgium pause and swell. 2 From thy awful rock serene Holy Freedom! hear and bend; Thine the heroes, thine the scene, Thine the cause; great Power, descend: On raven plumes involving all Brooding Death unfolds the pall! 3 'Tis not Superstition's groan, Frantick yell or sullen moan, Philip's gloom or Alva's frown Call thy righteous vengeance down; Godless The French Revolutionists. monsters stalk around: Hear, and guard this favour'd ground! 4 Lo, beyond the eastern gate Britain bold confirms thy state; By Aurora's earliest beam, By the proud and mystick stream, O'er the prostrate Tyrant's Tippoo Saib. sway India hails thy opening day. 5 See, arous'd in Virtue's cause, Sacred rights and equal laws, Armed nations pour the prayer: Bid the avenging Eagle bear Thy thunders from the realms of Emperor of Russia. Paul: Rise, and crush the monster Gaul. 6 By AndrastÃ¨'s radiant throne, By the sphere and wizard stone. By old Mador's druid lyre Struck with more than Theban fire, Thy words of potency infuse Breathing o'er the patriot Muse. 7 Lingering on the Belgian shore Hallow'd tears see Albion pour O'er the grave where warriors sleep, Victors of the subject deep: See Honour, Virtue, Justice mourn, Clasping sad their rostral urn! 8 Holy Goddess, hear and spare! Give thy chosen heroes rest: Though steep'd in crimson streams of war, Soon be the sword in olive drest. Written on the supposition that Thomas Chatterton, a native of Bristol (a youth who died before he had attained his eighteenth year not having received a learned education) was the author of the celebrated poems attributed to Thomas Rowley in the fifteenth century. ODE. 'Tis done: the wizard Genius gave the word: Instant round Bristol's crowded mart Beams of celestial glory dart, And to each kindling breast poetick joys impart! Give me the harp, he cried, of thousand strings: Echo from her mountain cell O'er desert heath or shadowy dell The repercussive notes in varying pauses brings: The obedient power of Inspiration heard. Now swell the strain in accent bold, Now tun'd to artless woe Let the soft numbers musically slow, Or to the praise of heroes old Let Freedom's war-song sound in thundrous terror roll'd. Far hence all idle rhymes, The taste of none but giddy-paced times: In manlier modes I strike the deep-ton'd Iyre, And other joys inspire. Whence is this ardour? o'er my labouring soul What wildly great emotions roll? It is decreed: Illusion! come: work thy all-potent deed, And deal around the land thy subtle dole. Be the solemn subject drest In antique numbers, antique vest; In Time's proud spoils right gorgeously array'd, With many a strange conceit and lore profound; There be the book-man's sapient art display'd, While Folly dreams, and Wonder stares around. Lo, Fancy wafts her radiant forms along, Borne on the plume sublime of everlasting song. Brave Richard Rowley's Second Eclogue. calls: the crescent falls: He rears the cross; the nations bow: Vengeance, arise! great Bawdin The death of Sir Charles Bawdin: dies: Awful be the notes and slow. Juga's Elinoure and Juga. woes demand the strain: Shall female sorrow stream in vain? Ah, deck with myrtle wreaths that hapless hearse: Nor let sainted Charity, The Ballade of Charity. Godlike maid with upcast eye; Unheeded pass without one votive verse. Change, my lyre, thy numbers change, And give aspiring thought an ampler range. Mark, where the Norman The Battle of Hastings. canvas swells afar, And wafts the destin'd troops to Albion's strand: Hear, Harold, hear! the distant sound is war, War that shall sweep thee from thy native land. The measure's clos'd: the work's dispos'd: Hang the immortal tablet high! The colours mix; the soul they fix; Confest before the entranced eye. Confirm, ye Powers of verse, the august design: And stamp with Rowley's name each consecrated line! THE END.
